text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with crispy everything flatbread

that's right not only do these
everything bagel inspired flat breads

taste twice as good as anything from the
store

they are also like 20 times cheaper to
make yourself okay if you priced a box

of fancy crackers or flat breads lately
I mean it's kind of crazy although that

wouldn't necessarily be a good enough
reason to make these yourself if they

took a long time and we're really hard
to do but these are not these are

actually quite simple to make
not to mention fun so with that let's go

ahead get started by making a very very
primitive dough which will begin with

two different flours some white
all-purpose flour and then an equal

amount of some kind of whole-grain flour
and today I'll be using some sprouted

spelt flour which is my personal
favorite whole-grain flour but use

whatever you want and then to that we
will add some salt as well as some

freshly ground black pepper and of
course a couple shakes of cayenne and

then because we're mimicking and
everything bagel we will add some

granulated garlic or garlic powder which
is the same thing only finer as well as

some onion powder or again granulated
onion and I'll talk about those subtle

differences in the blogpost and that's
actually going to be it for the dry

stuff and what we'll do at this point is
take a whisk and give this a mix and we

will stir that for about a half a minute
or so or until we think everything is

evenly distributed and then once that
set we can stop and we'll add a little

bit of olive oil followed by some very
warm water all right basically something

close to how bath water and then what
we're gonna do is get in there with our

bare hand and mix this until we formed a
nice smooth ball of dough and as you do

this you're probably gonna have three
different thoughts the first one would

be this stuff is way too wet it's not
gonna work followed by this is way too

dry it's not gonna work and then finally
once it all comes together

the third thought you'll have is oh no
wait this is fine it totally worked and

now I feel bad for doubting chef john
well you know what it's fine don't worry

about it
those are completely normal feelings and

I still get them but you'll see
eventually you will end up with a

beautiful nice smooth
lately soft but not sticky dough and

then what we'll do once our dough's been
bald is go ahead and wrap it in plastic

and let it rest for about an hour or so
which you can do right on the table if

you want or if it's gonna be a little
longer go ahead and pop it in the fridge

which is what I did and then when we're
radies it we'll go ahead and pull it out

and we will unwrap it and cut it in half
since I think it's probably a little

easier to work with half at a time and
then what we'll do on a floured surface

let's go ahead and press and roll this
out into a rectangle about an eighth of

an inch thick or less and as usual we
will only use enough flour to keep it

from sticking all right a little bits
always okay but we don't want to work a

lot of flour into the dough otherwise
we're gonna end up with a little bit of

a tougher product than we want and then
what we'll do as soon as that dough is

rolled out as thin as we want which like
I said is going to be about an eighth of

an inch or maybe slightly under is that
we'll carefully pick that up and

transfer it onto a lined baking sheet
and we'll go ahead and smooth that out

and then what we need to do at this
point as soon as our dough has a pan

under it is brush the top very very
lightly with water okay we don't want a

sopping wet but we do want that surface
a little bit moist and slightly sticky

and that's so that the seasoned we're
about to add properly it here so we'll

go ahead and very lightly but thoroughly
brush that all over at which point we

can go ahead and sprinkle over our
sesame seeds and our poppy seeds which

besides the onion and garlic are the
signature ingredients on in everything

bagel and by the way any edible seeds
gonna work here so if you want to use

something else feel free
I mean you are after all the Bill and

Ted of this excellent crispy flatbread
so if you're feeling adventurous you

could use things like chia seeds or hemp
seeds or flax any of that stuff will

work just fine with this technique and
then besides the seeds I like to finish

up a little sprinkling of sea salt I'm
using some beautiful fleur de sel from

France which has a lovely large grain
and then what we'll do is give this a

gentle pressing before we flip it over
which may seem like an unnecessary step

but it is not it is so so necessary and
I'm definitely going to explain why in a

few moments
but what we'll do is go ahead and flip

that over before taking a pizza cutter
or dull knife and cutting this into

whatever shape pieces we want all right
we can go squares we can go triangles or

we can attempt to do some diamond shapes
like I'm doing here which is done by

making some straight cuts lengthwise and
then making some cuts across it like 45

degrees and while I'm doing this I will
explain the reason we flipped the dough

over so the seeds are underneath it so
that as these bake the edges will curl

in the right direction okay a properly
made seeded flat bread will always have

the seeds on the concave side never on
the convex side and by the way that's

all gonna be a lot easier to understand
what's this bigs but anyway we'll go

ahead and cut those any which way we
want at which point they are ready to

transfer into the center of a 375 degree
oven for about 20 minutes or so or until

golden brown bubbled and very crispy
okay if these things are still soft and

flexible after they cool you did not
cook them long enough but these were

perfect so I'm gonna go ahead and flip
them over and as I'm doing this you can

really see why we wanted to flip that
dough over so the seeds were on the

bottom okay because the way the edges
curl up as this bakes now we have all

our beautiful seeds on the concave side
of the cracker which would always be the

side we'd want to dip or spread stuff on
all right if our seats are on the convex

side that just seems kind of weird I
mean it's gonna taste the same

but I don't want to be spreading things
on a hump which I find very

disconcerting and then very important
before we pack these away or pile them

up in a basket like I'm gonna do we have
to let them cool completely otherwise

they're going to kind of steam and get
soggy so I went ahead and let mine cool

before I transfer them into a cracker
basket which is a basket for crackers
and I went in for the official taste

and because of our garlic and onion and
salt and sesame seeds and poppy seeds

these really are delicious enough to eat
by themselves but let's not kid

ourselves since that's probably not
gonna happen and you may have already

seen these paired with a beautiful sweet
potato hummus which really was

absolutely amazing so these are going to
be perfect with any dipper strata or of

course paired with a nice soft
preferably funky cheese like this one

here for example that I forgot the name
of alright fine I didn't forget it's

French and I can't pronounce it but
that's not important what's important is

it it was magnificent
or should I say magnifique and then for

one final serving suggestion since the
everything bagels would inspire these

they really would be incredible with
some smoked salmon cream cheese on top

with maybe a little bit of caper red
onion and chive and of the half a dozen

different ways a these this was probably
my favorite Bob regardless of which you

serve these with or whether your seeds
are on the concave or convex side I

really do hope you give them a try soon
so head over to food whooshes dot-com

for all the ingredient amounts of more
offal as usual and as always enjoy
you
you
